column10: Defendant admits to being highly emotional, yet has a reasonable explanation for events, which is suspicious. The crossing paths on campus can't all be councidental, the roommates explanation of his reaction to being told to go away is more likely than his, and so on. Finally, after several months of rejection, he persisted. When would it end?

I felt that a reasonable person would be very fearful in this situation. It's one thing to send emails, but just sitting at her work, showing up outside of her classes, and speaking with her professor was way out of line.
Her stories are very elaborate in how the emails were invading her line of privacy. She also did not engage in any violence or escalation. Her safest move was to file a case

If he had been asked to stop in writing, like with a restraining order, and still continued, I think that would be stalking. But the only piece of evidence indicating stalking is the photo from the mall. The rest lines up with them just having a similar school schedule. His emails were inappropriate and made her uncomfortable, but I wouldn't call them stalking.

I believe there is a lot of circumstantial evidence and eye witness testimony. However, I would like to read the email transcripts, see surveillance footage, GPS logs, and review any other digital evidence that may indicate the level of stalking that is alleged to have occurred. Recent scientific evidence suggests that eye witness misidentification can lead to wrongful convictions

I have been stalked. It is a horrible violation of boundars. Mr. Jones was not being encouraged by this young woman. She quit sending emails so he should have quit sending them to her. She sent her friend to tell him to stop. That was a boundary. He refused to abide by this. Had the Security Officer taken this seriously, he could have had a conversation with Mr. Jones and told him to stop emailing and bothering this young woman. Any reasonable person would understand that if you do not respond to overtures, that means they aren't interested. Mr. Jones caused unnecessary trauma by ignoring her boundaries.
column67: A man was suing Owens Corning because he had asbestosis decades after he allegedly worked with that company's products. We had a hung jury.
column69: With Owens Corning, I felt the defendent was not guilty. The man suing had smoked for 50 years and had lung disease. It could have been from smoking more than it could have been from working with an asbestos product 50 years earlier. It was obvious his wife was greedy for money. He was mowing his grass up to his late 70s then had lung disease.

column10: The preponderance of evidence shows Mr. Jones engaged in stalking behavior that caused Ms. Klein substantial mental distress

The defendant was stalking the plaintiff. He continued to stalk her even after her roommate told him not to do so. The plaintiff was afraid of the defendant and approached public safety multiple times to get extra security. The defendant went so far as to even talk to the plaintiff's professor. He was clearly following her around campus and at her job.
I believe that the defendant did stalk the plaintiff. Especially after he was told to back off, he did not. Even his own testimony gave off the frightening vibes of a stalker.
column67: None. It was a civil trial about a car accident.

column10: He never approached her aggressively, he stopped once he was told that he was making her upset, and the security officer felt that there was not much to do

Clearly, his actions demonstrated enough to raise serious concerns to the plaintiff.  If it was enough to make her file a lawsuit, she was scared.  Period.  She was scared and she didn't know what else to do.  She went to security, they were of no help.  She asked her friend to tell him to stop this behavior, that was of no help.  What other recourse would she have?  In my opinion she did the right thing in filing the lawsuit.
I found that there was just not enough proof that there was any ill intent behind Mr jones actions. Mr jones did seem a bit obsessive but didnâ€™t seem dangerous.

I was leaning somewhat towards the plaintiff due to her detailed and forthcoming testimony and the testimony of her roommate describing confronting the defendant directly. I was swayed even further in her favor by the defendant admitting in his testimony to many of the actions the plaintiff described as troubling her. The addition of the security officer who admitted to not taking her concerns seriously because the defendant didn't have a criminal history didn't help matters.
The defendants communications and showing up to her place of work, after being told to stay away from her roommate, crossed a line.

The defendant described that he was pushing too far to be in touch with the plaintiff in ways that seemed to cause her concern. The security officer did confirm that something was going on even if they didn't believe it was a serious concern.

I believe Ms. Klein was in fact being stalked. Mr. Jones admitting that he kept pursuing Ms. Klein even after she asked him to stop, showing up where she was at and saying he just wanted to hang out because they had a good time dating. The plantiff was overstepping boundaries.

I found in favor of the plaintiff because of the evidence against the defendant. All the emails, the witness that told him to leave her alone. The plaintiff tried to get help from campus security. The defendant caused her to haves anxiety and feel unsafe.

column10: While I sympathize with the defendant when it comes to having a hard time letting go of someone they really liked, he was asked directly to stop multiple times and didn't.  He acknowledged that.  At that point, the reasons he was pursuing her don't matter.
I think thatbpeople become obsessive and that's how people getbhirt

I think the plaintiff made it very clear that she was NOT into the defendant, she didn't want to date him, but he still pursued her, and harrassed her. In particular approaching her professor, and lying to him, was disturbing (about them being current boyfriend/girlfriend), this is unacceptable.
My ruling was led by the acts of the plaintiff. The plaintiff initially responded and didn't directly tell the defendant to stop necessarily.

Overall, the woman was being stalked. The messages on social media with their pictures, the emails, lurking around where she had classes despite saying it was for other reasons, it's all evidence that would make someone worry for their safety. It's clear he stalked her and was not trying to win her back because a normal person would take a hint, not continue on with uncomfortable actions.
column12: I would award her the full amount she was asking for because this clearly affected her mental health and ability to provide for herself and she needed extra medical help to ensure she would be able to continue to live a normal life despite this trauma.

column10: The defendant wouldn't take no for an answer despite her consistent refusals and kept love bombing the plaintiff.

Most of the behavior of Mr. Jones could be chalked up to having a broken heart. However, he crossed the line twice in my opinion: once when Ms. Martin told him to stay away from his old flame, and secondly by showing up like a phantom at the plaintiff's place of work and outside her classroom. A mature, stable individual would not engage in this type of behavior. As I stated, his initial actions were reasonable and understandable, but his later activities were completely unacceptable and easily interpreted as potentially threatening.
The defendant failed to stop his behavior when requested by plaintiff and friend. He questioned others about her and were a lot of places where plaintiff was. He had behavior that was obsessive.

That if she wanted his attention after her roommate came by his room, after that, if she came by to me jones, then this would not be a good case. Hmms Klein did not require his attention though after her roommate went to his dorm room so, she did not care for me jones the way he might have like ms Klein.

There were a lot of red flags from Mr. Jones, and I believe even in his testimony he unwittingly admitted he was in the wrong. Ms. Klein also mentioned he was sending recent photos of her at the mall without her knowing he was taking them. It doesn't matter if someone has a history of violence; that can change quickly. He showed up to her work, and made her uncomfortable. He inquired why she wasn't attending classes or showing up to work, which is incredibly unwell behavior. There may not have been violence, but there's no telling if it could have led to that. The security guard I believe failed at his job or just didn't want to do it; 15 years is too long and he probably just didn't care. She should have went to the police and filed a restraining order and presented all of the evidence. Mr. Jones was obsessed over one person and couldn't move on. He was absolutely stalking her, without question, from the photos, and knowing when she didn't show to certain places, etc. A normal, rational and healthy person would have just moved on instead of hounding someone who was obviously not interested...
column12: I cannot award her a sum without knowing how much therapy she would need, or how much work she missed (assuming six months?), but could have possibly just gotten another job. Asking for heightened security at her dorm was also not really reasonable. I also don't believe she'll have future lost wages; only the wages she lost when she stopped showing up to her job because he was frequenting it with ill intentions. I believe this left out a lot of necessary information. For six months of missing work, and maybe six months of therapy (depending on insurance) I might award $6000, but I'll be honest... nobody sees money in civil cases... I won't award any mental suffering as that would fall under therapy and loss of work.

column10: I can understand why the plaintiff was worried but nothing was explicitly threatened
No one has the right to make another feel fear because they want to be with them.  He has no right to follow her around like that.

The defendant continued to contact and follow the plaintiff even after being told to stop. The plaintiff was clearly negatively effected by his actions as evident by missing class and continuingly calling campus security.

While I do find the plaintiffs actions to be a bit excessive, I don't feel as if they were over the line whereas the defendant was damaged to the point of requiring to be compensated 10,000 for the trouble caused by the defendant.

The plaintiff was being stalked by her ex-boyfriend, and it was causing her a lot of distress. He even admitted that her roommate had told him to leave her alone, but he kept on trying to contact her anyway. It's obvious that he is obsessed with her and can't accept the fact that their relationship is over.
Mr. Jones continued to make Ms. Klein feel uncomfortable after he was told it was not appropriate by her and her friend.

I feel that although the defendant had good intentions when he ontacted the plaintiff in an effort to win her back, once she made it clear that she didnt want to be contacted anymore, all attempts should have ceased.
the defendent seemed like he just wouldn't stop harassing her. the emails and the other friend getting involved is what made me make him feel guilty

The plaintiff had made clear that she didn't want to continue contact. The defendant continued pressing contact after he knew this was unwelcome. That is irrational and would make me feel threatened were I in this position.
column67: Civil jury re. wrongful death in a medical setting
column69: Civil case divided initally but I was convinced on liability early on

column10: I made this ruling because Mr. Jones continued to try and contact Ms. Klein after her roommate told him not to. Ms. Klein had every right to be scared because he continually contacted her, posted pictures of them and followed her.
column67: Possession of drugs for two juries and criminal sexual conduct for the other time
column69: Only the one drug case was not unanimous and I thought the defendant was guilty.

column10: I rolled in the defendants favor. I felt that he was not doing anything threatening to the plaintiff which would harm her.

The thing that puts this over the top for me was when he approached the professor to ask about her health because she missed classes.  That is a disturbing amount of monitoring and behavior.  It does bother me as a father of girls.

There was no evidence that the defendant had caused any physical danger or harm to the plaintiff. Mr. Parker, security officer for Westernshire University for nearly 15 years, also stated that he had looked into Mr. Jones' file and saw nothing alarming or any history of criminal conduct. Additionally, Plaintiff should have not responded to any of Mr. Jones' emails if she felt her safety was being threatened. Overall, no evidence of potential harm or danger, while I understand the Plaintiff is concerned of Mr. Jones' behavior, she is not entitled to damages, ruling in favor of the defendant.

column10: very good

I am convinced he was stalking her. He approached the professor stating he knew she had missed classes. That shows me a possessive personality. He wanted to make assumptions she was playing hard to get. He kept inferring she really cares when she doesn't. The amount of $10,000 is about fair i think.
column12: I think $10,000 is reasonable in this case. She definitely had some mental anguish, but I feel it wasn't over the top. She was trying to handle him, so that shows she didn't feel totally frightened.

column10: How he talked about her, he clearly was DELUSIONAL about their relationship and I totally BELIEVE that he WAS STALKING her and didn't listen when the roommate told him to STOP sending her roommate emails but he REFUSED and his answers were NOT normal at all.

Although Mr. Jones claimed no ill intent, his actions did cause significant distress to Ms. Klein and caused her to have difficulty in her academic and professional pursuits. Lack of physical harm does not mean there was no harm. Further, the security officerâ€™s blowing off the complaints despite the numerous attempts by Ms. Klein to obtain more security seems less like evidence of no problem and more like evidence of a culture which downplays and ignores the experience of the women, particularly in cases where men make women feel uncomfortable or threatened with their actions or words.
column68: I do not know because I was dismissed early due to being unwell
column69: N/A (was not present for the verdict)

column10: The defendant took no actions that harmed or threatened the plaintiff.  Actions like posting photographs of them when they were dating are normal behavior. She was fearful, but that was due to her anxiety more than any real threat. He seemed more concerned about her than anything else.

he lied when he stated that their paths were simply crossing and he should have stopped his behavior when it was clear that she had no interest in the relationship. Even though he represented no physical threat, the situation would reasonably cause emotional distress.

If she says she is feeling threatened then she is feeling threatened. We have to trust women when they say things before things get really out of hand. She has no reason to lie. There was multiple times and chances that he had to leave her alone and he didnâ€™t take any of them. I do believe she suffers from emotional distress and I do also believe that I would feel the same way if it was me dealing with this.
going to her place of work and not ordering anything and staring at her.   Thats not a public place and he should not of been there without being a paying customer
This behavior seems annoying but not dangerous. No threats were made and he did not contact her directly.
He is obsessed with her and if he is not stopped, he might escalate.

The defendant acted in a crazed and obsessive behavior that any reasonable person would consider to be unreasonable, if not downright dangerous and scary. I feel he needs to be taught a lesson, if nothing else.
I think his actions did rise to the level of stalking but I feel as if the amount of damages is too high.
column12: I would award her $5,000 because I do not think she will endure a great amount of future lost wages.

column10: Evaluating Evidence: The jury carefully considers all presented evidence, both direct and circumstantial. Direct Evidence: This evidence directly proves a fact without the need for inference, such as eyewitness testimony, confessions, or recordings. Circumstantial Evidence: This evidence implies a fact through inference, such as fingerprints at a crime scene or a suspect's behavior. The jury must logically connect the facts presented to reach a conclusion about guilt or liability.
column12: Compensatory damages are money awarded to an injured party that compensate for damages, injury, or another incurred loss.
column66: Each court randomly selects qualified citizens from counties within the district for possible jury service. All courts use the respective state voter lists as a source of prospective jurors
column67: Felonies, being the more serious category of crime, almost always qualify for a jury trial due to the potential for severe penalties, including lengthy prison sentences. Misdemeanors, while still serious, often carry less severe punishments and, as a result, may not always necessitate a jury trial.
column68: Civil Trials: In a civil trial, the outcome can be a verdict (a decision by a jury) or a judgment (a decision by a judge, especially in bench trials). Possible outcomes include a finding for the plaintiff or the defendant, and if for the plaintiff, the determination of damages (monetary compensation). Damages can be compensatory (to cover losses) or punitive (to punish the defendant).
column69: Jurors are free to discuss the case after being discharged by the judge, but they are not obligated to do so. Discussions during deliberations are generally protected by confidentiality rules to ensure jurors can freely discuss the case. Attorneys are often interested in speaking with jurors after a hung jury to understand the reasons for the deadlock and potentially adjust their approach for a retrial.

column10: The defendant has crossed the line not once, but many times. The defendant is suffering from mental delusions and although it is not up to the court to decide this, it must be entered into the record. His behavior is criminal in nature. Conveniently waiting, watching, approaching and contacting are all unsolicited assaults when they continue after they have been rebuffed. Guilty.
column12: $10000 is not sufficient. This creep must be deterred.

column10: I made my decision based on the actions of the defendant. I thought about the events and what took place. I thought that the plaintiff gave notice that she wanted to be left alone, yet he persisted. The plaintiff took many actions to have the defendant to leave her alone and let him know she wasn't interested.

The plaintiff presented a reasonable case.  The defendant was stalking her and causing her distress.  He persisted in sending emails, following her on campus, contacting one of her professors inappropriately, and ignoring the pleas her roommate presented to him.
column12: I would award her $10,000 to pay her attorney fees and cover some of her lost wages.
column67: One was civil case; criminal case involved domestic violence.
column68: Civil case decided for plaintiff.  Criminal case decided for plaintiff with monetary compensation for injuries sustained.

column10: I think they are both at fault. But since, I was flagged for a wrong answer on that decision, I have to choose in favor of the Plaintiff. I believe Jessica Klein could have been more clear and explained to the Michael Jones why she did not want to see him anymore. Michael Jones, still overly pursued Jessica Klein, and is at fault for that.
column12: The amount they are asking is fine, $10k. If the amount contains the lawyer fees, she'll be lucky if she sees any of it.

column10: The defendant has a good case

Although the defendant never physically harmed the plaintiff he did pursue and pressure her after being told to leave her alone and stop all contact with her. He should have left her alone after she asked many times to be left alone. Whatever reason he had to continue to contact her after their breakup was not sufficient enough to continue because she felt unsafe.

I did not see adequate evidence of stalking to justify a claim for such significant financial loss. The situation is unfortunate but I don't see how it clearly rises to the level of civil/legal liability. These experiences are not uncommon given the passionate feelings that young adults often have surrounding their relationships.
it seems clear the the defendant was stalking the plaintiff, possibly non intentionally but none the less pain and suffering was caused by it
column69: have not been in this situation

column10: He was stalking her plain and simple.
While there was no physical distress, there was significant emotional distress. He had a repeated pattern of bothering her in excess despite multiple attempts to get him to stop.

The Plaintiff did not mention asking her boss to ban the annoying and non-paying customer from the cafe. She did not mention trying to transfer to another college. She did not mention telling her professor to stop talking with her ex. She did not mention scheduling classes at the same time as several athletic and large friends. She did not mention calling family members to visit her often. She did not exhaust every option before calling upon security and the legal system to help her. Asking for help from security or the legal system is stupid in this kind of situation.

The defendant's actions were enough to make anyone feel scared or threatened...that doesn't necessarily mean they would actually be harmed, but the plaintiff had no way of knowing that for sure. He was asked to back off and he didn't because he thought she was being hard to get. He needs to realize no means no.

I ruled for the defendant because they had been in a relationship and Jessica had told Michael to email her.  I did not feel that he was a threat.  I also don't think his actions would cause mental distress to a reasonable person. I had a similar situation in college where a guy kept showing up after class or when I was out having lunch and it was annoying but I do not feel it should be considered stalking.
column67: 1) civil regarding employment 2) DWI  3) burglary  4) grand jury
column68: 1) defendant prevailed 2) guilty 3) guilty 4) issued true bills or no bill for 6 months
column69: The juries I've been on have reached unanimous verdicts and I personally agreed.  On the grand jury I considered the evidence presented and had to follow the law.

column10: Iâ€™m kind of regretting the decision I just made.  I think the plaintiff was both fearful and annoyed, but that a reasonable person would only have been annoyed.  I do think the defendant was being innappropriate and annoying, and selfish, and may need this case to get a clue.  I think the plaintiff was unreasonable to expect more security, but tgat Parker is bad at his job, and should have spoken sternly to the defendant, and made it clear he was being told by the school to stop.

I chose in favor of the defendent because I did not see any direct concrete evidence that he meant to cause the plaintiff harm or distress. Although I am sympathetic to the plaintiff for having to put up with the unwanted attention, I believe it is fair to believe the defendent when he says he had no idea he was causing her distress.

Well the evidence isnâ€™t clear. It would be nice to see the emails but she said the emails started out nice but became aggressive. If thatâ€™s true she would be scared and suffering mentally which would be justified if he needed to pay fir her therapy bills.

column22: The largest and most noteworthy factor is Mr. Jones went up to one of her professors, calling himself her boyfriend raising concerns. His defense to that was nonsensical. The security officer of the university admitted that the plaintiff was scared. The chronology of events documenting stalking are far stronger itemized by the plaintiff, and the defendant saying "she doesn't know how much I loved her" and things like that indicate he's not respecting her decision. The campus/school had ample opportunity to warn Jones to stay away or be removed from school. I tend to think resources of extra security are ambiguous but the school failed minimal safety here. There's no excuse for the school to not communicate directly to Jones that he either stays away from meeting or directly looking for the plaintiff or he's expelled. Basically, there's too much evidence that he's stalking her and she's scared, even if we can "guess" he wouldn't do something, we don't know for sure. I'd say it's far more likely the plaintiff was stalked, the university failed the most minimal responsibilities, and the defendants own testimony is obsessive and refusal to respect her wishes to be left alone.
column24: I would award her $30,000 mostly because while I think it's not a perfect conclusion that the defendant would've done something and while the school has to decide what resources or actions are fair, the school overwhelmingly failed to provide minimal protections. Those minimal protections would've been to tell Jones immediately and unambiguously to stay away from the plaintiff and if there's any direct evidence he's stalking or going out of his way to meet or stalk her, expelling him would be on the table. At the same time, I don't think it requires a huge judgement as the damages are not that large. Essentially I can envision lost wages, stress and mental suffering so I figure 30k might pay her for a free year of tuition thanks to the universities failures.
column67: I served on a grand jury once where there were endless drug crimes, a few violent crimes, a sexual crime like illegal photos on a computer and such, and things like that. Lots of difference criminal stuff. Then I served a few days on some civil action if my memory serves.
column68: As grand juror probably 95% of our votes were for indictment because the cases brought forward had high evidence. The civil verdict was for the plaintiff I believe.
column69: Every stance I took on a jury vote or verdict was unanimous as far as I remember.

column22: The defendant was clearly stalking the plaintiff and I can see why she felt very uneasy and felt like she needed additional protection that she did not receive from campus security. He should not have been at her workplace, he should not have repeatedly reached out to her and it was none of his business if she missed class or not. I can see why she was frightened and felt like she wasn't receiving help.

According to the transcript campus security never even contacted Mr. Jones about his problematic behavior.  Just because he's got nothing in his file to suggest hes a danger.  Doesn't mean he hasn't had a mental break or something of that sort.  They should have at least swung by him doom room and given him a heads up.  Maybe a guy in an authority position would have gotten Mr. Jones to wake up.
column24: $5000, thats just about $200 for therapy every other week for a year.

column22: They had no authority do do anything about this alleged stalking. He had no record and there was no cause for concern other than the plaintiff's complaints.
Westernshire University appeared to perform as they should have in this situation and no obvious situations putting the plaintif in danger were identified
I believe she was truly scared and she tried to follow the proper protocol several times.

I am disappointed that the reaction by the university is similar to what I feel most places do (which is to be reactive rather than proactive and wait until the bad thing happens to actually show any concern). I think it's obvious she feared for her safety, her fears were dismissed, and this guy thought he could just get away with anything and everything and didn't care that he was making her uncomfortable. What a creep. He needs counseling. Gross.
I feel the school had done more to engage the stalker and maybe even offer him help or counseling.g

The security officer testified that he could tell that the plaintiff was scared, but he kept blowing her and her concerns off as if they were nothing. This tells me that the plaintiff was absolutely correct when she said that the University did not do what it should have to help her. In addition, the defendant's statements exhibited clear signs of a stalker's mentality, and thus the University should have taken this case seriously.

The plaintiff brought up repeated claims to campus security and they did nothing. A visit to Mr. Jones could have stopped his behavior and made him realize the seriousness of the situation.  The plaintiff did suffer enough for me to.feel the 51% threshold had been crossed

Legally speaking, Mr. Jone's behavior met the definition of "stalking." Not only this, but the behavior continued even after he was informed that it was causing the plaintiff distress. And, per his own admission, he WAS aware she was in distress by virtue of her missing her classes. In addition to the mental anguish of being stalked, she also suffered academic and financial consequences as a result of his actions. These actions could have been interrupted or inhibited by the University but they declined to intervene at every stage. Early-intervention, such as speaking to Mr. Jones, or providing Ms. Klein with an escort, might have discouraged him from engaging in this behavior. Regardless of physical harm, or the security officer's "impression" of Mr. Jone's background and behavior - the fact of the matter is that he was engaging with the plaintiff in a way that was unwanted and distressing. And he was doing this on campus. They had a responsibility to create a safe environment for their student and failed to do so.
column24: 8000. I am removing 2000 from the request of 10 because, while Ms. Klein did suffer mentally/financially and physically, she herself never undertook direct action to get Mr. Jones to stop his behavior. She had her roommate ask him to stop, but she never do so herself - opting to intervene through other people only.

column22: I do believe the defendant was stalked somewhat but there was no actual physical harm to her or a really serious threat.

This is clear emotional distress.

column69: I remember thinking they were guilty

column22: Mr. Jones acknowledged that he behaved in the ways he was accused of behaving. The university did not take Ms. Klein's concerns seriously despite her frequent contact.

I considered that she had lost work and missed classes and I think that would be sufficient evidence for the university to at least do something about it. I considered the plaintiffs concerns to be relevant after I read about the strange and obsessive behavior by the defendant. I considered why there was only 1 security guard that was involved in the decision making process for whether she needed extra security and also why was the professor not a witness.
No actions were taken that would have caused a normal person to feel as if they were being stalked.

Both the plaintiff and her roommate reached out for help and were denied.  The defendant did not take due diligence in investigating the matter further when the calls for help increased, instead ignoring them.

column22: I think she was being stalked and the school didn't care.

I really think that Ms Klein did THINK that she was being stalked by him but with just some e-mails, a Facebook post and coincidences of him being where she was, that is probably happening to a lot of students, not just her. He has no criminal record of any kind and I think he just really thought he would "win" her back by showing he cared about her.The security officer had 15 years experience and didn't see a stalking problem, so that says a lot. In my opinion, if she really thought she was being harassed and/or stalked and wasn't getting what she wanted from the university, she would have tried to go to the police department.
it seemed like it there wasn't much you could do. the plaintiff should have requested a TRO from the govt, so that campus security has a reason to act on her compliants.
If any harm happend and if any further conflict happened in which it did not so there was nothing really wrong here. They both go to school on the same campus so they would see each other
there was no physical harm and one safety officer said it was not serious enough

The plantiff did provide a lot of evidence in favor of their case. The defendant excessively bothered the plantiff which made them very afraid and fearful  The staff at the university ignored the plantiff's claims due to them not seeing anything wrong in defendants file.

Plaintiff ased to be left alone after becoming uncomfortable with repeated contact and emails that are described as having highly emotional content. She even sent a friend to express the same wish. Defendant interpreted her behaviour as 'playing hard to get'. I would think that is not a common occurrence in today's dating landscape. While I'm not aware of any actual threats being expressed and with campus security assessing the situation as 'not dangerous', plaintiffs level of discomfort with it that seemed genuine influenced my decision.
It seemed that the overall preponderance of evidence was on the side of the female student.

This guy was clearly insane stalker I have had this happen to me. Granted the guy didn't get close enough to hurt me because my uncle beat the crap out of him which got him to finally realize i was scared for my life. This school needs to be held accountable.

Based on the situations presented I learned about two young people who lack relationship experience since neither of them communicated well nor did they understand or respect each other. Both made assumptions and held a bias in what they believed the other person thought or felt rather than focused on their own well being and handle the break up concisely and in a mature fashion. The young man behaved like a lost puppy dog with sexist notions of how to win back the girl and the young woman understandably felt fear since upbringing probably taught her to 'be nice' rather than stand up and assert herself since for women this means being seen as 'a bitch'. Both required intervention from a counselor and a course on healthy relationships, boundaries, and accepting rejection.
column69: One trial took extra deliberation since it came down to circumstantial evidence and reasonable doubt.

column22: The defendant himself admitted that he was a serious neiusance to the plaintiff and ignored her request to leave her alone. In addition to that the campus security guard also admitted that he could tell that she, the plaintiff, felt fear. Mr. Jones' engaged in behaviors such as causing distress, behavior that serves not purpose, following her everywhere she went, etc. that per the courts guidelines is textbook stalking. In addition to those acts Mr. Jones' lack or remorse is also very concerning and leads me to believe at some point he will in fact escalate. Ms. Martin the plaintiffs friend stated that he became angry, slammed his door, and made a menacing statement after she requested he leave Ms. Klein alone. Also, the campus security guard did NOT do hie due diligence. He simply looked up a file and determined that the claim was not worth his time and based his reasoning on past complaints. This was dangerous and stupid move as a slight nuisance could easily take a turn for the worst. The security guard could have at the very least brought Mr. Jones into his office and gave him a stern talking to but he did not even do that. To me it seems better to be wrong about stalking behavior than to ignore the complaint and be liable for a preventable death.
column24: I would reward the plaintiff the full amount of $10,000. This to cover the cost of the trial and other expenses as well as send a message to the university about failing to investigate serious claims.

column22: I agree that the woman was in distress and that the man did not leave her alone despite multiple requests. Knowing that the university is watching him might have made him back off.

The man was clearly stalking her and that's what we're deciding, right? The university should have done more. DOne anything. It's insane that we just let this stuff happen until the girl is actually physically hurt and then the law can do something about it. Something needs to happen before it gets to that point. I was terrified by what that buy said and how he spoke about the plaintiff and the situation in general. Terrified, so I can't imagine how that girl felt.
The plaintiff did not suffer any physical harm. The defendant exercised due diligence in examining the complaint.
The defendant did not stalk the plaintiff

I decided in favor of the plaintiff because the university did not take action even after Ms. Klein reported feeling unsafe many times. Mr. Jones's repeated behavior caused her emotional distress, and the university failed to protect her.

I think Mr. Jones did a number of things that could be considered more than just a coincidence or a misunderstanding. For instance, if Mr. Jones did not email Ms. Klein again after his initial email then I would not have considered that to be harrassment. Likewise, if he had made only one Facebook post I would say you could label it as a misunderstanding on Ms. Klein's part. It was the combination of all the things Mr. Jones did that made me believe he was stalking Ms. Klein and I believe the university is liable because not even once did they give Ms. Klein extra security even though she asked many times. If they had done that at least once then I would have leaned more toward a 50/50 case between the plaintiff and defendant.
column67: Driving while under the influence of alcohol resulting in a single car accident
column68: The defendant pleaded guilty after the prosecution presented its side of the case
column69: Based on just opening arguments and the prosecution's side of the case I think the defendant was guilty

column22: I found in favor of the plaintiff because it was clear that she was scared and being stalked, but nobody would listen to her or do anything about it. They acted like she needed to be physically harmed before they would do anything, and many times that is too late. Ms Klein did tell Mr Jones he could email her, but after her friend told him to stop, he should have left her alone.

There is no question that the plaintiff was being stalked. The stalker all but admits it. The university was negligent in protecting her from her stalker. Campus security was fully aware, yet deeemed his stalking not serious enough to warrant extra security detail for the plaintiff.
I believed the plaintiff. The defendant was not believable.
column68: DUI not guilty.   SHOPLIFTING  NOT GUILTY

column22: She had evidence that she filed a report about her fears and nothing was done.
The university did nothing to try to stop the stalking
Attitudes, beliefs, experience, and personality types are the factors that will most accurately predict and influence jury decision-makig.

When Mr. Jones was on the stand he stated that after being told by the friend that Ms. Klein no longer wanted any contact with him, he continued. Further, had the security guard told him the same after the first call the situation may have dissipated. If not, he'd know it's far more serious and would (hopefully) take further action. However, his "investigation" simply had him looking for a criminal record in his school records and nothing further. That doesn't suffice to me. There was no real investigation into the complaint.

column34: Certainly the fact that the Mr Jones was insistant was really awkward, but nothing bad really happened and there could be some other reasons for the fact they were meeting from time to time.
I feel that this was a case of misunderstanding between both persons. I don't feel that Michael possed  any threat to his ex-girlfriend, but simply wanted to win her back.
By the definition of stalking, this does not meet the criteria. Defendant was not putting the victim in danger sexually nor death. I considered all the witnesses, evidence, and my own judgment.

I found the evidence proved beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant commited the crime of stalking when he put the victim in fear. A reasonable person would have been in fear given the facts of the case. The victim repeatedly asked the defendant to leave her alone, and the defendant did not comply. The defendant persisted against the victim's wishes. The victim was constantly on alert and in fear she may run into the defendant. The victim made several complaints that went ignored. All these facts establish guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
column36: 6 months in jail and a $500 fine.
column69: Both trial were a unanimous verdict

column34: The authorities were called and thatâ€™s when he should move on. Itâ€™s a waste of time for the court to sign off on a restraining order.
column36: He should pay a fine. The judge should give him a notice that he may have to serve probation if he doesnâ€™t take classes for stalking. The court should also warn him of whatâ€™ll happen if this were to happen again.

column34: The plaintiff offered no record of previous abusive behavior or valid reason to believe that the defendant would commit any harmful acts.

I think he is guilty because he took things too far. After multiple attempts for him to stop especially when the roommate asked, he should have stopped but did not. He also claimed that he left her at the theater when he thought she seemed afraid but contradicted himself by saying later on, he did not stop pursuing her because he did not know she was scared.
column36: He should serve a month in jail and have to pay $100.

column34: You can understand the case of the woman; she is so fearful of this man, she quit her job where he was showing up constantly, writing her emails constantly, security couldn't do a thing for her, and she has trouble sleeping, eating, and getting good grades in her class. This woman was frighetened and scared beyond belief and she felt trapped and paralyzed because of this man.
column36: Yes, he deserves a year in jail and to pay 450 dollars to the state.
column69: They did reach a unanimous decision on it and they found him guilty.

column34: I don't believe that Mr. Jones met the two criteria to be convicted of stalking. Yes he might have been overbearing but he did not threaten the plaintiff.

He was told that it was bothering her and continued as well as saying he was sure she still loved him even though there was all evidence that she did not and wanted to be done with any involvement with him.
column36: Paying a fine of 500 dollars.

column34: Mr. Jones never threatened or made unwanted advances.  I also don't believe that Ms. Klein ever told Mr. Jones that she was upset by his behavior and that she was having trouble with him and/or his behavior towards her.
column67: Minor offenses such as petty theft, traffic accidents, etc

column34: She was afraid of him.
column36: Pay a fine only

column34: If he really loved her so much he would leave her alone, especially when she had indicated that is what she wanted several times. No means no, not 'convince me'.
column36: 6 months and $500 to the state

column34: Mr. Jones did not deny sending repeated emails or following her; plus, the defense said the only thing proved was his love, which is not behavior indicative of love  -repeated attempted contact resulting in eventual ignoring by the victim
column36: $400 fine, one month jail

column34: The female victim was frightened for her safety and the defendant was not leaving her alone with his delusions of winning her back because he loved her so much.
column36: 10 months jail and $400 fine

column34: The fact that he continued to email even after she stopped responding, and talking to the professor. It just seems out of character.
column36: $500 fine

column34: He stalked her for almost 5 months. From the first time in theatre he felt she was not comfortable as he admitted. He found out she was annoyed by him in December and continued to be in touch with her till January.
column36: Maximum fine of $500

column34: There was no evidence that Mr. Jones had the character of a person that would harm another with physical abuse or other harm.  I think he acted more like a lost puppy.  Ms. Klein failed to communicate to Mr. Jones that she felt threatened by the continued presence of Mr. Jones in her life after they broke up.  Ms. Martin going to Mr. Jones to basically say, "stay away from her" did not convey that the victim was feeling threatened.  The extreme number of calls to Campus Security seemed over the top and indicate more of a neurotic personality on the part of the victim to believe that Mr. Jones contacts were threatening.

He didn't directly make threats to her and I don't recall her directly herself telling him to leave her alone and that she is not interested, she sent someone else to, she should have just told him that himself.

mr jones sent an enormous amount of emails stalked her outside of work when asked to stop he DID NOT. He then asked professors and her friends why she had been missing classes which clearly seems like he needed to know where she was
column36: 6 months in jail and a 500dollar fine

column34: This was a tough decision for me! I decided on not guilty only because he did not threaten her. He was guilty of making her fear for her safety but refrained from direct threats.
Klein responded to a lot of attention from Jones, emails, visits, things like that. She harassed security for no reason. Jones was never mean, never threatening. Klein was being dramatic.

The defendant's behavior would likely cause most people to be fearful. His claim that he is in love with Ms. Klein does not give him the right to stalk her. I am a psychologist and professor and I would be concerned if someone asked me about one of my students (Ms. Klein in this case). Ms. Klein was likely quite upset by the complete failure of the security department to do anything. Apparently, they did not have time to meet with the defendant. A meeting with security can have a quick effect under the right set of circumstances/
column36: One month in jail and a fine of $500.

column34: I feel that the he is not guilty as he had threatened Ms. Klein directly.
He continued to pursue her after both she and her friend asked him to stop. Whether he intended physical harm or not, she reasonably feared for her safety.
column36: Stay at least 100 feet from victim at all times, undergo psychological counseling, and pay a fine. I don't feel jail time is warranted at this time.

column34: while the defense's argument was that it wasn't conduct enough to be stalking, i felt the facts proved it to be 100% stalking. Not to mention the emotional distress he was causing by his behavior.
column36: 5 days in jail with supervised release and fine

column34: Even though his intentions may not have been malicious, he did technically stalk the victim. The act was further confirmed because he was told that the victim wanted to be left alone, but he still continued to try and engage with her.
column36: I have decided to give the defendant the maximum punishment of 12 months and to pay a fine of $500.

column34: He was asked multiple times to stop contacting her or trying to contact her and he didn't.
column36: I believe he should pay a fine only. no jail time.

column34: It was admitted that he was trying to make unwanted contact. He didnâ€™t make explicit threats but did say things like how she would regret not getting back together with him. She took reasonable efforts to dissuade him which were unsuccessful.
column36: I believe the punishment should be a fine, no imprisonment, and community service. This shows it was serious but would not disrupt his academic life.
column67: First was a traffic accident. Second was juvenile sex trafficking.
column68: First was found for the defense. Second was a mistrial.

column34: She was scared for her safety, that's clear by how much she contacted security with concerns. The guy admitted he basically stalked her in a clueless "I love her" way, and that would make anyone concerned. No means no, and in this case She clearly told him no and didn't want him around. Yet he did anyways. He stalked her without a doubt, and she knew it, and was scared for her safety.
column36: 9 months, no fine.

column34: I do believe that he behaved in a way that would make anyone feel uncomfortable but I believe that it was U to the victim to tell the defendant to leave her alone. None of that evidence ever had the victim telling the defendant how uncomfortable he was making her feel or asking him to stop emailing her or to stop posting pictures You're here he sounded like creep but he really just sounded like somebody really cared about the victim and the victim did not care for him but never once told me the defendant that she wanted him to stop any of the behavior that any of it was making her feel uncomfortable or fearful in any way. If he had been told to stop his behavior and it had continued after that then I would have a different opinion.

I don't know how intense this situation would have gotten if she had not brought him to court. It did appear that he had met the criteria to be charged. The purpose of the law would be in my opinion to prevent this man from proceeding further without though for his own safety and reputation.
column36: At this point I would say 500 fine and no jail time unless he starts again.

column34: He was told repeatedly to leave her alone but did not a reasonable person would have taken the hint and stopped.
column36: Pay the 500 dollar fine and 5 days in jail.

column34: I believe Mr. Jones was not intentionally trying to do harm or cause Ms. Klein to be fearful or have to worry about her safety. Although he was persistent, he never threatened her and seemed only to really care about her ans was lamenting the fact that they had broken off the relationship. I also believe the testimony of the security officer helped Mr. Jones' case in that he had been there 15 years and was able to compare this situation with other alleged 'stalking' cases he'd seen in the past. This just seemed more of a case of someone not wanting to let go of someone he was in a relationship and seemed blown out of proportion by the plaintiff.

He was in love with her and wanted to win her back, so he persisted in ways that he thought would make her care about him again. He did not know and did not realize that the victim was fearful. He also did not make any threats or say anything that would cause her to be fearful of her safety. He was just persistent and unwanted, not harmful.

I belive that based on where they both go to school, they could easily cross paths. Even if he did approach her, he left her alone after the fact and did not push the matter. Due to lack of evidence I don't feel comfortable saying guilty.

I don't think there was evidence that he threatened sexual contact, serious injury, or death. I think he's an absolute creep and she absolutely is fearing for her safety, but so far, the prosecution has not proved that specific criteria for stalking. I feel terrible for her and his actions warrant severe consequences in my opinion, but the law as written is limited and fails to protect victims of stalking.
Facts of your case. The facts surrounding the crime that you are charged with committing and the evidence that the prosecutor has against you will play a huge role in your case.
column36: not to exceed

column34: He wasn't going to hurt her if he would he would've done it earlier he should just get a warning about the stalking ..she isnt interested you cant force a girl to love you..he should take the warning and dissapear from her life.
Pictures recently taken,  contacting her professor, sitting at work...those are intentional behaviors
column36: Pays the fine, no jail time, stays away from the prosecutor

column34: There was no further contact after the roomate told him to leave her alone and that she wanted nothing to do with him. At first I could see her point but if he stopped when she said stop then it was trying to win her back not stalking

He persisted and continued to try and contact her and be around after she made it very clear that she was not interested, no matter how innocent it seemed to him or whether or not he intended to harm her physically. Clearly he saw her as inferior to him in some way by believing that she doesn't know what she needs. He needs a reality check.
column36: I think the best way to handle it would be an injunction against harrassment. I don't think jail time is necessary. maybe a $300 fine.

column34: Even though he made no outward threats, any reasonable person would fear for their safety given the extent of his stalking
column36: I would not give jail time but I would assess the maximum fine

column34: I believe he is guilty but there is no evidence that he directly threatened her in any way which was a requirement for a guilty verdict

I feel he is is niave but not to the point of not knowing what he was doing was wrong. He had people directly telling him to stop what he was doing and did not question his actions. He persistently interacted with her after being told this.
column36: I would not like him to serve any jail time but I believe a fine of $500 would be acceptable.

column34: The kid was just trying to get his ex back. They go to the same school, they are going to cross paths. She could have easily told him herself to stop or that it made her uncomfortable, but she never did. She had a friend do it instead, which can be misconstrued as meddling by the friend. All she would have had to do it told Mr. Jones to stop herself.

the constant emails, being at her workplace and him constantly reiterating that he loved her. If he truly did he would have lef her alone. The constant calls to security for assistance shows that she was worried and fearful.
column36: He serve 2 months and pay the maximum fine.

column34: He never caused her any harm at all, he never threatened her or anyone that she knew. He loved her and thought he could win her back. She was never clear with him about leaving her alone. She never told him to leave her alone and stay away from her. He never broke the law.

The fact that both the plaintiff and the defendant agreed that the plaintiff told him to stop and that he wouldn't stop should be enough "evidence". I'm particularly disturbed that the plaintiff had to get someone to tell him to back off and he wouldn't. Worse, the campus police took a very relaxed attitude and said it would blow over. But now he's being made to testify in a stalking case. It's almost an even split by gender how people see this. The women are concerned, and the men think they're doing the right thing. It's abhorrent.
column36: He should do six months in jail, plus a $500 fine to the state.
column67: Both were drug offenses. One was a criminal offense, and one was a civil offense. The civil offense was over a drug store that was over selling narcotics, and eventually shut down. The victims were seeking restitution.
column68: The criminal case was a guilty verdict, and the civil case was found liable.
column69: In both cases, it was pretty clear. On a personal note, my father was one of the customers to the pharmacy in the civil trial.

column34: Despite being told over and over to leave Ms. Klein alone, Mr. Jones persisted.

Mr. Jones needs to realize that his actions were in excess and needs to be held accountable.

I agree that if Mr. Jones was a stranger or barely knew the victim, then it would be stalking, but in this situation, it was nothing more than an inconvenient  attempt at getting back with an ex. The woman blew it out of proportion, she herself made actions that led him on and encouraged him to keep trying. This should be dropped.
Not enough reason to support case imo

The main factors that influenced my decision is that he was told by Ms. Klein's roommate to leave her alone and he didn't. The other strong piece of evidence is that he spoke to her professor about her being out sick, showing 1) he was stalking her to know when she was at school/work and not, and 2) that he was crossing boundaries by speaking to her professor about her.
